titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Dorothy Goldeen Gallery Records, 1961-1996, bulk 1987-1996, in the Archives of American Art AAA.dorogolg
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Carrol Park

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-19T10:17-0400

did.abstract: The records of the southern California Dorothy Goldeen Gallery measure 4.0 linear feet and date from 1961 to 1996, with the bulk of the items dating from 1987 to 1996. Included are artists' files and files on six group exhibitions. Artists files may include correspondence, printed material, resumes, slides, and photogaphs of art or artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of the southern California Dorothy Goldeen Gallery measure 4.0 linear feet and date from 1961 to 1996, with the bulk of the items dating from 1987 to 1996. Included are artists' files and files on six group exhibitions. Artists' files may include correspondence, printed material, resumes, slides, and photogaphs of art or artists.

Artists particularly well-represented in the records include Ciel Bergman, Jo Ann Callis, Mary Campell, Michael Dvortscak, Heidi Fasnacht, Patsy Krebs, Terence La Noue, Ken Riddle, Lyn Bell Rose, Italo Scanga, Paul Tzanetopoulos, Daniel Weiner, John White, and Allee Willis, among others. There are gaps in the records and several well known artists that Goldeen showcased are not extensively documented.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Dorothy Goldeen Gallery (1987-1996) was an art gallery in Santa Monica, California founded by Dorothy Goldeen.

Dorothy Goldeen's professional career began in 1973 in San Francisco with the Hansen Fuller Gallery which later became Fuller Goldeen Gallery. In 1987, Goldeen relocated to Los Angeles and opened the Dorothy Goldeen Gallery. Historically significant artists such as Magdalena Abakanowicz and Nam June Paik were represented as well as influential, emerging Los Angeles artists such as Diana Thater and Jennifer Steinkamp.
In 1996, after twenty-three years as a fine arts dealer, Goldeen closed her gallery and launched the Dorothy Goldeen Art Advisory in Santa Monica.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Dorothy Goldeen Gallery Records, 1961-1996, bulk 1987-1996. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The records were processed in January, 2005 by Pamela Conway and a volunteer, John Norris. A finding aid was prepared by Carrol Park in 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 2 series.

list.item: Series 1: Artists Files, 1961-1996 (3.9 linear feet; Box 1-4)
Series 2: Group Exhibitions, 1988-1996 (0.1 linear feet; Box 4)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Dorothy Goldeen Gallery Records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. Permission to pubish, quote, or reproduce must be obtained from Dorothy Goldeen.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Dorothy Goldeen Gallery records were donated by Dorothy Golodeen to the Archives of American Art in 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Within this series are Dorothy Goldeen files relating to featured artists at the gallery. Of note are artist files on Magdalena Abakanowicz, Nam June Paik, and Brazilian painter, Beatriz Milhazes. Folders typically contain letters, exhibiton catalogs, resumes, slides, photogaphs of art or artists, and greeting cards.

did.unittitle: Terrence La Noue and Charles Ginnever
Terrence La Noue and Dennis Leon
Daniel Lavi and Kenneth Riddle and Zody Zellen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes files related to group exhibitions at the gallery. Found here are notes and biographies on a jewelry show, as well as slides for the Fresh Visions exhibition. Folders may contain correspondence, photographs of art, invitations, posters and fliers, invoices, and price lists.
